title: State Department Officials Berated Staff Over Views, Report Says
summary: Inspector general cites management deficiencies at Bureau of International Organization Affairs. The State Department's inspector general said in a report that high-ranking department officials berated career employees over their political views, questioning their loyalty and retaliating against some of them.

title: Stopping Red Ink Tops WeWork's To-Do List
summary: We Co.' s growing losses suggest office-space company will need large sums of cash for years. As WeWork heads toward an initial public offering, the office-space company faces a fundamental problem: Its losses are growing as fast as its revenue.

title: A New Rule of the Trucking Road
summary: The feds want to give drivers more flexibility to drive more safely.. Regulation can do more harm than good, especially regarding safety. This reality is behind an overdue update this week of a federal rule on truck-driver hours.

title: Still Heading for the ObamaCare Exits
summary: New data show enrollment is falling fast for the unsubsidized.. Republicans think they can win on health care in 2020 by running against Medicare for All, and the facts about single payer are a target-rich environment. But the latest data on ObamaCare shows why the GOP needs to come up with its own ideas to sell to the public.

title: Israel Blocks Visit by Two Critical U.S. Congresswomen
summary: Israeli government takes action amid pressure from President Trump, who tweeted that the pair should be barred. TEL AVIV-Israel on Thursday barred U.S. congresswomen Rashida Tlaib and Ilhan Omar from entering the country amid pressure from President Trump, who said allowing them in "would show great weakness."

title: Treasury to Sell $94 Billion in Debt
summary: U.S. Treasury Department next week will auction 13- and 26-week bills and 29-year, six-month TIPS. The U.S. will auction $94 billion in securities next week. Details (all with minimum denominations of $100):

title: Democratic Lawyer Craig's Trial Opens Over His Work for Ukraine
summary: Former White House counsel is accused of misleading government about work arranged by Paul Manafort. WASHINGTON-The trial of President Obama's former White House counsel opened on Thursday, promising to shed new light on the inner workings of Washington lawyers, public relations firms and journalists.

title: A Tabloid Legend on Jeffrey Epstein's Death
summary: This is the story with everything. Wealth, power, darkness. Princes and presidents with secrets.. This week we turn the column over to the late Mike McAlary (1957-98), tabloid star and journalistic tough guy. Here's Mike:

title: Central Bankers in Glass Houses
summary: The Fed was politicized long before Donald Trump got to the White House or even started tweeting.. What to make of the current battle over the politicization of the Federal Reserve? The past year has featured an unprecedented attack by President Trump on Fed leaders and their independence. Mr. Trump not only questioned the board governors' judgment but even contemplated removing the chairman for the sin of not setting interest rates where the president wants them. In reaction, four past Fed chairmen recently co-wrote an op-ed on these pages to remind the country that short-term political pressures can undermine the proper long-term objectives of monetary policy.

title: What Hong Kong's Protesters Know About Business
summary: The real economic dangers come from Beijing and the damage it deals to the city's rule of law and reputation.. One of the odder tics in discussions of Hong Kong's 10-week political trauma is the notion that the protests rocking the territory are bad for business. Something nearer the opposite is true: These protests are one last chance to preserve the city's economic reputation, at enormous cost-and risk-to Hong Kongers, who understand exactly what's at stake.

title: It's No Felony to Violate the Law of Contradiction
summary: TV hosts and rivals love to catch candidates' flip-flops, but an intelligent mind should change sometimes.. 'The test of a first-rate intelligence," wrote F. Scott Fitzgerald, "is the ability to hold two opposed ideas in mind at the same time and still retain the ability to function." Few are the contemporary politicians able to pass that test. Among the paucity who might, cable-TV journalists of our day do their best to divest them of this exemplary quality by pointing up the egregiousness of their contradictions. So, too, do politicians in debate against rivals enjoy catching out an opponent in what they feel is a disqualifying contradiction.

title: 'All the Wrong Moves' Review: Life Is Better in Chessland
summary: The author's addiction to the game ﬁlls him with self-loathing. But when his girlfriend starts attending his matches, he's no longer ashamed.. In "The Luzhin Defense," Vladimir Nabokov's novel of chess and madness, the protagonist forsakes ordinary reality for the private universe of his interior chessboard. The painter and sculptor Marcel Duchamp not only forsook art for chess; he spent his honeymoon in a chess club in Nice, France. His bride glued his pieces to the board and obtained a divorce. Then there was Boris Spassky, the Soviet champion who wryly remarked of his doomed marriage: "We were like bishops of opposite color."

title: Former CFO of Cash-Advance Company Charged With Securities Fraud
summary: Alan Heide also agreed to settle related civil charges with the SEC. A former chief financial officer of a now-bankrupt Florida cash-advance company was charged by federal prosecutors in Miami with operating an alleged securities fraud scheme.

title: My Cousin Paul Died a Hero
summary: Elderly locals still remember the young man who fell saving France from the Nazis.. On Saturday four generations of my family and hundreds of members of the French public and political class will honor an act of courage that occurred 75 years ago.

title: Consign James Blaine to Memory Lane
summary: The Supreme Court may finally undo the legacy of 19th-century anti-Catholic bigotry.. American religious schools have gotten a bad deal for centuries, but they'll finally get their day in court next year. The Supreme Court recently decided to hear a case challenging Montana's anti-Catholic Blaine Amendment in its next term. The high court could unravel the antireligious bias written into the constitutions of Montana and dozens of other states-and improve the lives of millions of children trapped in underperforming public schools.

title: Fusion, the 'Collusion' Puppeteer
summary: Bruce Ohr's 302s, just released to the public, show Glenn Simpson pulling the strings.. The Justice Department is investigating how a former British intelligence agent, Christopher Steele, came to exert so much influence over the Federal Bureau of Investigation's erroneous Trump-Russia collusion narrative. Let's hope the department is also investigating an even more influential man who had even less business manipulating the government: Glenn Simpson, the head of opposition-research firm Fusion GPS.

title: Notable & Quotable: 'Murder,' She Wrote
summary: 'PolitiFact heard from numerous readers who asked us to check whether Harris and Warren were correct in calling Brown's death a "murder."'. From an Aug. 14 "fact check" by PolitiFact.org:

title: Federal Prosecutor Blames Police Shooting on 'Culture of Disrespect'
summary: U.S. Attorney William McSwain renews attacks on the city's district attorney, Larry Krasner. The shooting of six police officers in Philadelphia is inflaming longstanding tensions between the top two prosecutors in the city.

title: Nvidia's Earnings Show Signs of Recovery
summary: Chip maker posted $2.58 billion in revenue, beating a consensus from analysts surveyed by FactSet. Nvidia Corp. reported a third consecutive quarter of lower earnings compared with the year-earlier period, but posted sequential sales growth that boosted investor sentiment about its financial recovery.

title: Latin American Airline Group Notifies U.S. Authorities of Foreign Bribery Investigation
summary: Avianca Holdings said the potentially illegal business practices may have involved senior management and certain board members. Latin American airline group Avianca Holdings SA is investigating whether it violated U.S. foreign bribery law by giving free tickets and upgrades to government officials.

title: Rise of Electric Cars Threatens to Drain German Growth
summary: Industry executives worry that a transition away from fuel-powered vehicles threatens jobs, tax revenue. STUTTGART, Germany-Concern is rising in Europe's automobile heartland about the economic impact of the industry's move to electric vehicles from gasoline-powered cars.

title: GE Is New Target of Madoff Whistleblower
summary: Harry Markopolos releases report on GE's accounting, claiming its cash situation is far worse than disclosed and GE needs to boost insurance reserves. Company says claims are false, misleading.. An accounting expert who raised red flags about Bernie Madoff's Ponzi scheme has a new target: General Electric Co.

title: Mayor Draws on Father's Suicide in Dealing With Spike Among NYPD Officers
summary: Remarks come amid spike in suicides among New York Police Department officers this year. Mayor Bill de Blasio is trying to stem the spike in suicides among New York Police Department officers this year by speaking openly about his father's suicide in urging them to seek help.

title: Trump Urges Xi to Meet With Hong Kong Protesters
summary: The U.S. president said, 'there would be a happy and enlightened ending to the Hong Kong problem. I have no doubt!'. President Trump urged Chinese President Xi Jinping on Thursday to meet with Hong Kong protesters, arguing such a move would help end the crisis roiling the region.

title: Capital One Cyber Staff Raised Concerns Before Hack
summary: Cybersecurity employees reported what they saw as staffing issues and other problems to bank's internal auditors, human-resources department and other senior executives. Before a giant data breach at Capital One Financial Corp. , employees raised concerns within the company about what they saw as high turnover in its cybersecurity unit and a failure to promptly install some software to help spot and defend against hacks, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Cisco CIO Says Shift to Cloud Will Cut Energy Use, Costs
summary: 'We have a huge responsibility to make sure we're always thinking about how to optimize power consumption,' says Jacqueline Guichelaar. The chief information officer of Cisco Systems Inc. is investigating the possibility of shutting down several energy-guzzling data centers and transferring more data to public cloud services.

title: Dayton Gunman Had Drugs in His System, Coroner Says
summary: Toxicology report found cocaine, alcohol, antianxiety drug in Connor Betts's system. Connor Betts had cocaine, alcohol and an antianxiety drug in his system when he opened fire on a crowded street in Dayton, Ohio, in the early hours of Aug. 4, killing nine people, including his own sister, the Montgomery County coroner said.

title: Walmart Set to Outpace Amazon for 2019
summary: Shares gain after retailer posts higher quarterly sales, raises profit forecasts for the year. Walmart Inc. shares advanced 6.1% Thursday, continuing a winning streak this year that has lifted it about 21% and put it neck-and-neck with shares of a highflying tech favorite: Amazon.com Inc.

title: Argentina Peso Strengthens for First Time Since Primary Election
summary: Partial recovery may indicate some investors believe a possible Fernandez administration won't be so radical. Argentina's peso strengthened against the dollar Thursday, the first improvement for the currency since a left-wing presidential candidate performed better than expected in a primary election last Sunday.

title: Kate Spade Brand Drags Down Handbag Maker Tapestry
summary: Company lowered earnings guidance for the year; shares down 23%. Tapestry Inc. is showing that creating a house of brands to rival European luxury conglomerates isn't so easy.

title: Earnings Outlook for S&P 500 Companies Looks Bleak
summary: Wall Street analysts cut third-quarter profit estimates, adding to concerns including trade dispute. Investors counting on a corporate earnings rebound in the second half of the year are risking disappointment.

title: J.C. Penney Branches Into Used Apparel as Sales Tumble
summary: Retailer will offer secondhand women's clothing and handbags from thredUP; quarterly loss narrows. J.C. Penney Co. 's sales fell 9% in its latest quarter and the retailer said Thursday it would start selling second-hand clothes as part of a broader effort to transform itself.

title: GE Fraud Claim Doesn't Have to Be True to Hurt
summary: A report from an experienced investigator calling the conglomerate the next Enron underscores problems shareholders already know about. General Electric had enough on its plate before Harry Markopolos showed up.

title: Crude Prices Continue to Fall
summary: Worries persist that slowdown in global growth will hurt demand. Oil prices declined for a second consecutive day Thursday amid worries that slowing global growth will weigh on demand.

title: Revlon Exploring Strategic Alternatives With Help From Goldman Sachs
summary: Struggling cosmetics maker to look at selling all or parts of its business. Revlon Inc. has hired Goldman Sachs Group Inc. to help review strategic alternatives, including the sale of all or parts of its business, as the cosmetics maker copes with changing consumer tastes, a person familiar with the matter said.

title: Gov. Cuomo Wants to Prosecute Mass Shooters as Domestic Terrorists
summary: Proposal would create a new charge for any person who kills in a mass attack on the basis of race, religion, creed or sexual orientation. Gov. Andrew Cuomo on Thursday proposed a new state law to specifically penalize domestic terrorism, a response to recent mass shootings and what the Democratic governor said was inaction on the part of federal officials.

title: WeWork Bond Prices Surge on Buyback Hopes
summary: The company's pre-IPO disclosures indicate it may buy back bonds early. WeWork Co.'s debt is surging following the company's S-1 filing for a proposed IPO, as investors bet the company could retire bonds before they mature in 2025.

title: July Was Hottest on Record
summary: Climate change is largely responsible for driving average world-wide temperature last month past previous high in 2016, U.S. researchers say. This past July was the hottest month world-wide in more than a century of global record-keeping, with severe heat waves in Europe, Africa and parts of the U.S. boosting the overall global average temperature, federal climate scientists said Thursday.

title: Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous Professors
summary: Elizabeth Warren shows how to accumulate a small fortune while working at a 'non-profit' called Harvard.. Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D., Mass.) likes to talk a lot about an affordability crisis in higher education. Fortunately for Ms. Warren and her husband, there's no crisis at all for the people who work there.

title: 'Cola Wars' Review: What's in Your Glass?
summary: History's production looks at the Coke vs. Pepsi battle for your tastebuds.. Is the nostalgia-flavored "Cola Wars" a case of kicking an industry when it's down? Hardly. The American thirst for sugary soft drinks may not be what it used to be. But as pointed out in History's quasi-epic of commercial combat, it doesn't really matter what beverage you imbibe: If you buy it, and drink it, Coke or Pepsi probably owns it. Or will. And that includes the great scam of the 21st century, bottled water.

title: 'The Amazing Johnathan Documentary' Review: Slights of Hand
summary: A documentarian wages war against his untrustworthy illusionist/comedian subject.. Clashes between nonfiction filmmakers and irascible subjects have ranged from the comic to the combative to the tragic. Consider Errol Morris, dancing around with the evasive Donald Rumsfeld in "The Unknown Known." Director Jay Bulger having his nose broken by drummer Ginger Baker in "Beware of Mr. Baker." And the cameraman who was actually shot to death by the fascist gunman he was filming, as seen in Patricio Guzman's "The Battle of Chile."

title: Bank of Mexico Cuts Interest Rates as Economy Struggles
summary: Central bank cites slower growth, lower inflation and declining debt yields. MEXICO CITY-The Bank of Mexico lowered interest rates Thursday for the first time in more than five years in a split vote, citing slowing economic growth, lower inflation and a decline in debt yields in Mexico and abroad.

title: U.S. Stocks Stabilize on Strong Retail-Sales Data
summary: Investors' angst eased after data showed U.S. shoppers increased their spending in July. U.S. stocks advanced Thursday as upbeat data on Americans' spending habits helped to ease investors' fears about a possible recession.

title: Stocks Bounce but Fear Remains
summary: Near-dated futures contracts tracking the VIX continue to hover above those expiring later, a sign investors are girding for turbulence in stocks. U.S. stocks rose Thursday after a deep dive Wednesday, but fear is still percolating in the derivatives markets.

title: Alibaba's Sales Jump 42%, Beating Expectations
summary: Chinese online-commerce company continues to boom, more than doubling net profit. BEIJING- Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. reported a 42% increase in sales and more than doubled profit in its latest quarter, as the Chinese online retailer booms despite a saturated e-commerce market and an economy weakened by the U.S.-China trade conflict.

title: Walmart Continues Run of Sales Growth, Raises Forecasts
summary: Retail giant says online grocery sales and more efficient stores fueled gains. Walmart Inc. posted higher second-quarter sales and raised its profit outlook, extending a multiyear streak of growth as the retail giant takes market share from struggling competitors and expands online.

title: Fed's Bullard Says U.S. Economy Is Sound
summary: President of St. Louis Fed sees no need for extraordinary meeting of policy makers. Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis President James Bullard said Thursday the trade war between the U.S. and China is fueling uncertainty about the economic outlook but stressed that the domestic economy appears to be on sound footing.

title: Kashmir Seethes Under Indian Security Clampdown
summary: Road blockages and communication curbs thwart protests, but Kashmiris say 'the volcano will erupt'. SRINAGAR, India-As Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi promised peace and prosperity for the disputed region of Kashmir in an Independence Day speech, Indian paramilitary forces blocked off streets in its largest city, which has been under a nearly total communications blackout for more than 10 days.

title: U.S. Shoppers Splurge in Face of Global Headwinds
summary: Thursday's economic reports provide fresh evidence of a split between consumer-driven strength and weakness in manufacturing. WASHINGTON-American shoppers gave the U.S. economy a boost in July, countering manufacturing-sector weakness, while Wall Street continued to have jitters about faltering growth.

title: Mondelez, Kraft Heinz Cry Foul Over Regulator's Comments
summary: Food companies say trading commission violated terms for settlement of lawsuit over market manipulation. Two of the largest food manufacturers in the U.S. said the federal government's commodities regulator failed to hold up its end of a deal that settled a 2015 lawsuit related to alleged manipulation of the wheat futures market.

title: Detention Officer Placed on Leave After Truck Clash With Anti-ICE Protesters
summary: Rhode Island officials investigate incident in which immigration facility employee drove pickup truck into crowd. Authorities in Rhode Island are investigating after a detention-center employee drove a pickup truck into protesters outside a facility housing federal immigration detainees late Wednesday night.

title: As Trade War Rages, the Cupboard Isn't Bare at New York Food Banks
summary: The extra inventory has overwhelmed some charitable organizations. The trade war between the U.S. and China has led to an unlikely side effect: Some food banks in New York are bursting at the seams.

title: 'Cold Case Hammarskjöld' Review: Tangling a Mystery
summary: Mads Brügger's quasi-documentary takes a convoluted, self-reflective approach to the death of Dag Hammarskjöld, the U.N. secretary-general who died in a plane crash back in 1961.. 'Cold Case Hammarskjöld" reminds us how eager we are to make sense of impenetrable mysteries, and of possibly nonsensical movies. The man who concocted it, a Danish filmmaker named Mads Brügger, takes us down a succession of rabbit holes populated by shadowy creatures who may or may not be related to shaggy dogs. The trip is entertaining and even instructive-not about the facts of the case, which go from murky to opaque, but about the slip-slidingly elusive nature of truth.

title: 'Blinded by the Light' Review: Born to Inspire
summary: A teen of Pakistani descent growing up under the austerity of Margaret Thatcher's Britain finds a source of joy in the music of Bruce Springsteen.. As you watch "Blinded by the Light," don't let its earnest trappings blind you to the beauty of its core. Gurinder Chadha's coming-of-age drama transmutes the raw feeling of Bruce Springsteen's music into another kind of feeling, no less raw but leavened by giddy excitement that culminates in joy.

title: 'Aquarela' Review: Awash in Beauty
summary: Water in all its forms is the subject of this unusual documentary feature.. Instead of trompe l'oeil, which seeks to fool us, "Aquarela" is a triumph of trempe l'oeil. It seeks to drench us-in astonishingly vivid, often hallucinatory images of water. Victor Kossakovsky's documentary feature has no plot, no kinship with "The Shape of Water," and no readily discernible agenda, which is not to say it lacks purpose. The subject truly is H20 in all its power and various forms, from frozen to rainbow mist. A work of singular beauty and a significant technical achievement, the film makes water audible-the thumps and groans of calving glaciers sound like the planet coming apart-and almost palpable; heaving mountains of blue-black waves in an Atlantic storm convey stupendous mass and titanic energy as in no motion picture I've seen before.

title: Mick McGuire's Marcato Capital Loses 90% of Assets
summary: McGuire is a protege of William Ackman and counted Blackstone as a client. A well-known activist hedge fund that had the backing of billionaire William Ackman has lost more than 90% of its assets.

title: House Judiciary Committee Subpoenas Corey Lewandowski, Rick Dearborn
summary: Former Trump campaign manager and ex-White House aide both mentioned in special counsel Mueller's report. WASHINGTON-The House Judiciary Committee on Thursday subpoenaed two former Trump associates who the panel's Democratic chairman said were involved in President Trump's effort to impede special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation.

title: Burford Reassigns CFO After Investors' Concerns About Marriage to CEO
summary: Litigation-finance firm said investors clearly prefer an 'alternative' finance chief. Burford Capital Ltd. reassigned its finance chief, who is married to the chief executive, following investors' concerns about their relationship, the international litigation-finance firm said Thursday.

title: Net 'Censorship' and Community Standards
summary: In a week in which our nation is wondering how to stop hateful speech online, Dennis Prager complains about platforms applying their community standards when filtering videos and other content created by users.. In a week in which our nation is wondering how to stop hateful speech online, Dennis Prager ("Don't Let Google Get Away With Censorship," op-ed, Aug. 7) complains about platforms applying their community standards when filtering videos and other content created by users.

title: A Case for an Independent Federal Reserve
summary: So long as the Fed sticks to central banking, i.e. monetizing a portion of the national debt with monetary base, it can expect to be an independent expert agency.. Regarding Paul Volcker, Alan Greenspan, Ben Bernanke and Janet Yellen's "America Needs an Independent Fed" (op-ed, Aug. 6): So long as the Fed sticks to central banking, i.e., monetizing a portion of the national debt with monetary base, it can expect to be an independent expert agency.

title: Time to Pull the Plug on Afghanistan War
summary: If the Afghan government is unwilling or unable to stand up to the Taliban after almost 20 years of American support, it will never be ready.. While I have the utmost respect for Gen. David Petraeus, I couldn't disagree with him and co-author Vance Serchuk more ("The U.S. Abandoned Iraq. Don't Repeat History in Afghanistan," op-ed, Aug. 10).

title: 'Into the Woods' Review: Stunning Simplicity
summary: Stephen Sondheim's fractured-fairy-tale parable of innocence and experience gets a stripped-down staging at the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival.. Garrison, N.Y.

title: 'Sea Wall/A Life' Review: Double Trouble
summary: Two dramatic monologues, by Simon Stephens and Nick Payne and performed on Broadway by Tom Sturridge and Jake Gyllenhaal, offer uninspired views of modern masculinity.. New York

title: Recipe for the Ultimate Chicken-Salad Sandwich
summary: Colorado chef Caroline Glover has high standards when it comes to this lunchtime classic. Her fresh, unfussy version is the kind you could eat every day. A CHICKEN SALAD must never be gloppy-this is the first of chef Caroline Glover's stipulations. It should always taste of just-roasted chicken and never be slippery (go easy on the mayo) or cloying (no grapes). And there should be some kick. If served on a sandwich, the bread should have bite and hold the salad, not succumb to it. Beyond a crisp lettuce leaf, nothing else is required.

title: A Skeptic's Guide to Wine in Cans
summary: Canned wine is trending, touted as the perfect pairing for beach, ballpark and beyond. But can a can really rival the pleasure of uncorking? To find out, our wine expert committed to a week of pop-top pours. WHEN WAS the last time you purchased a wine for a particular sport or outdoor activity-a Pinot Grigio for a beach volleyball game, a rosé for a round of golf or maybe a bubbly to bring along to the ballpark? Until recently, my answer was never. But canned-wine makers are betting that's what more drinkers want to do, and they seem to be right.

title: Hickenlooper Exits Presidential Race, Mulling Senate Campaign
summary: Former Colorado governor along with Beto O'Rourke of Texas are among the presidential candidates being urged to run for Senate, but wouldn't go unchallenged. Former Colorado Gov. John Hickenlooper's decision to drop out of the crowded Democratic presidential field and consider a Senate run signaled that party leaders' efforts to press low-polling candidates to follow such a path could be making headway.

title: FDA Pushes for Graphic Health Warnings on Cigarette Packs
summary: Effort has failed once before when a court ruled warnings violated First Amendment. The Food and Drug Administration proposed a rule requiring cigarette packs to feature graphic health warnings, including color photos of smoking-related illnesses.

title: Robert De Niro and Nobu Matsuhisa Want You to Go to Their Beach Club
summary: The actor and chef, cofounders of the growing Nobu Hotels brand, on great food cities, a stolen bathrobe and the 'very special place' they're building in the Caribbean. THE TEAM behind the growing band of Nobu Hotels, which launched in 2013, are like the Traveling Wilburys of hospitality. Chef Nobu Matsuhisa figures he's on the road 10 months out of the year and is sometimes joined by his sundry partners Robert De Niro, film producer Meir Teper and CEO of the enterprise, Trevor Horwell. "It's not easy, but this is my life," said Mr. Matsuhisa, with an impish smile. Fairly persuasive as an actor, Mr. De Niro convinced him to bring his trailblazing Japanese cuisine, which he first tasted in California in the 1980s, to Manhattan in 1994. "That type of food didn't exist anywhere-not in London, not in New York," said Mr. De Niro. "So I said [to chef Nobu], 'If you ever want to open in New York, let me know.' It was simple." They are now partners in 42 Nobu restaurants around the globe. Mr. De Niro reckoned they had nothing to lose by tacking hotels onto their dining rooms. The first Nobu Hotel opened in Las Vegas six years ago, and they're on track to have 20 hotels, from Malibu to Warsaw, by 2020. Mr. De Niro and Mr. Matsuhisa spoke to us-when they weren't cracking each other up-in Midtown Manhattan about flying commercially, rare downtime and the film that inspired a trip (no, not "Taxi Driver").

title: Power Tools: Which to Buy, Which to Rent
summary: Four handymen hammer out which home-improvement machines you should purchase and which you should pay to use. WHAT TOOLS do you truly need? I recently posed this question to a few handy friends at a backyard barbecue. One pal, Jaf Farkas, a set builder for films, advocated for the "less-is-more" approach. Unless you're a general contractor, he said, big pricey tools like table saws chew into precious garage space. Plus, since tech evolves rapidly, it's smarter to rent top-end, well-maintained tools than worrying about upkeep of aged ones you own.

title: Gibraltar Releases Iranian Tanker Despite U.S. Intervention
summary: Release from overseas British territory was delayed by U.S. application to seize the vessel itself. Gibraltar released an Iranian tanker that the British overseas territory impounded in July, opening the way for Tehran to free a British-flagged vessel it subsequently seized and help ease tensions in the Persian Gulf.

title: How Sony's Walkman Created Headphone Culture
summary: As the Sony Walkman turns 40, we scrutinize the iconic tape deck's impact on popular culture: the way we imbibe our chosen audio, discover music and shut out the world. SOON AFTER its 1979 launch, Sony's Walkman was already seen as much more than a trendy audio player. Crucially, it became an escape hatch.

title: No One Can Fly Like Simone Biles
summary: The American gymnast builds on her legend with gravity-defying moves-and by holding power accountable. Simone Biles can fly.

title: ECB Primes Big Bazooka for September
summary: The central bank is preparing a 'very strong package' of stimulus measures to support the flagging eurozone economy. HELSINKI-The European Central Bank will announce a package of stimulus measures at its next policy meeting in September that should exceed investors' expectations, a top official at the central bank said.

title: Subha Barry on Getting Women Interested in Stocks and Bonds
summary: She contends 'women are almost naturals at managing money' in WSJ's Secrets of Wealthy Women podcast. Subha Barry, who spent over two decades in the financial services industry, says women often abdicate investment decisions to their spouse.

title: Care.com Needs Supervision
summary: Activist investor calls for Care.com to consider a sale, but even that may not be enough to restore parents' lost trust. Care.com 's days as an independent matchmaker could be limited.

title: Mythic Images on a Grand Scale
summary: A new exhibition of the art of William Blake offers him the mass audience he never enjoyed in his lifetime. William Blake (1757-1827) was born into the age of Enlightenment, but scientific reason and logic had no place in his work. In the books of poetry and prose that he both wrote and illustrated, Blake elaborated a complex mythology about a world full of angels and demons who battled for control of the human soul.

title: Georgia's New Voting Machines Must Be Ready for 2020 Primary, Judge Says
summary: Order follows lawsuit over security of state's outdated machines, which provide no paper record of votes. A federal judge ordered Georgia to have new voting machines in place throughout the state by the 2020 primary election in March or have plans to provide voters with paper ballots.

title: Consumers to Bond Market: What, Me Worry?
summary: Strong retail sales and results from Walmart suggest that fears of a recession sparked by an inverted yield curve may be overblown. If the Treasury market is signaling an imminent recession, somebody forgot to tell U.S. consumers.

title: New York City Introduces Wait Lists for Students Unhappy With School Placements
summary: City's complex school-choice system, in which students hope to be assigned to a top pick, has long been daunting for many families. New York City families unhappy with their offers to public middle and high schools will have a new process involving wait lists to get different placements, officials said Thursday.

title: Smartphones: Know When to Fold 'Em, When to Hold 'Em
summary: Another reported Huawei delay could give room to Samsung-assuming any prospective foldable-screen customers are left. Among other things, 2019 was to be the year of the folding phone. But the laws of physics keep getting in the way.

title: Buying a Home, No Matter the Market
summary: An analysis of the top seller's, buyer's and second-home markets in the country, plus expert advice from real-estate agents and house hunters. Is luxury real estate up or down? Hot or cold? Buyer's market or seller's market? These are questions that seem impossible to answer, given the old truism that all real estate is local.

title: ECB Takes Hacked Website Offline
summary: Central bank says malicious software was implanted on its BIRD site. The European Central Bank, which supervises data protection at Europe's largest banks, said Thursday that it temporarily shut down one of its websites after it was hacked and injected with a malicious software.

title: Does Fishing Have a Future?
summary: As the young turn away from the sport, companies and schools look for new ways to reel them in. Paul Harris remembers driving to the New Jersey shore in a Ford Model A to go fishing with his father.

title: Briggs & Stratton Shares Drop After Guidance, Dividend Cuts
summary: The Milwaukee-based company reports wider loss and announces plans to consolidate production of small vertical-shaft engines. Shares of Briggs & Stratton Corp. plummeted more than 40% on Thursday after the gasoline-engines maker posted a surprise quarterly loss and slashed its dividend and earnings guidance.

title: They Played on the Main Stage at Woodstock 50 Years Ago-No, Really
summary: Resume Subscription. To recall the list of bands and performers who played the Woodstock Music & Art Fair in 1969 is to revel in rock 'n' roll glory: Jimi Hendrix, Janis Joplin, Santana, The Who, Grateful Dead and Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young.

title: You Should Definitely Track Your Loved Ones' Phones. Actually Maybe Not.
summary: Apple's Find My Friends, Google Maps and Life360 let you stay on top of your family and friends' locations; they can be incredibly creepy and incredibly helpful. It's 10 p.m. and I know exactly where my family is-or at least where they're plotted on a map. My sister is safely in the kitchen of her house. My wife? Turning the southwest corner of the park walking the dog. My father is in the ... lake? Technical glitch. Phew! He's on the deck.

title: The Lonely Burden of Today's Teenage Girls
summary: Amid our huge, unplanned experiment with social media, new research suggests that many American adolescents are becoming more anxious, depressed and solitary. "I have friends with debilitating problems like cutting and OCD [obsessive compulsive disorder]," a girl named Jordan recently told us. "It's frustrating because I can't help them. I mean, I'm only 14 myself."

title: China's Paramilitary Police Flex Muscles Opposite Hong Kong
summary: At a Shenzhen sports stadium, thousands of young officers exercise, military vehicles at the ready. SHENZHEN, China-In recent days, thousands of young paramilitary police have moved into a sports stadium in a residential district of this southern Chinese border city-a show of force to a restive Hong Kong less than five miles away.

title: Is Your Cumin Current? A Guide to Buying and Storing Spices
summary: A new way of selling spices demystifies the process to deliver greater flavor and freshness. ASK ANYONE who knows him: Chef Meherwan Irani is impossibly nice. But when it comes to spices, it doesn't take much to provoke a rant. "You'd never store your coffee for two years in a glass jar next to the stove and expect a good cup of coffee," he said incredulously. "We know the provenance of coffees and chocolates, our meats and produce. But we know nothing about spices."

title: No Sign of China's Slowdown at Alibaba
summary: The country's e-commerce giant has made a successful push into smaller, poorer regions. China's economy is slowing, but e-commerce giant Alibaba Group Holding has found a way around the problem: pushing into smaller, poorer cities.

title: China Renews Vow to Retaliate Against Planned U.S. Tariffs
summary: Beijing says Trump's latest threat, which was partially dialed back Tuesday, violates earlier consensus reached between the two leaders. BEIJING-China renewed its vow to retaliate against U.S. tariffs set to be imposed in coming weeks, despite President Trump's decision to delay implementing some of the levies, but expressed hope the two countries would reach a resolution to the trade war.

title: Philadelphia Gunman Taken Into Custody After Hourslong Standoff
summary: The suspect shot and wounded six police officers. A suspect who shot and injured six Philadelphia police officers was taken into custody early Thursday morning, officials said, after a nearly eight-hour ordeal that included a gunfight and tense standoff in the northern part of the city.

title: 'Shooting,' 'Bomb,' 'Trump': Advertisers Blacklist News Stories Online
summary: Resume Subscription. Like many advertisers, Fidelity Investments wants to avoid advertising online near controversial content. The Boston-based financial-services company has a lengthy blacklist of words it considers off-limits.

title: Forget Stocks. Ultralong Bonds Are the Real Gamble.
summary: Buying bonds at such stupidly high prices isn't a way to keep your investment safe-it is speculation. In the old days, the government bond market was the calm, dependable one keeping a watchful eye on its excitable equity-market sibling. No longer. Bonds are now just as good a place to be if you like to bet on big price moves, and stocks-while not exactly a tranquil place to invest-haven't moved any more than is usual.

title: Dogfights in the Danger Zone
summary: Aerial combat was born during World War I, giving the world a new kind of military hero: the fighter pilot. "Top Gun" is back. The 1986 film about Navy fighter pilots is getting a sequel next year, with Tom Cruise reprising his role as Lt. Pete "Maverick" Mitchell, the sexy flyboy who can't stay out of trouble. Judging by the trailer released by Paramount in July, the new movie, "Top Gun: Maverick," will go straight to the heart of current debates about the future of aerial combat. An unseen voice tells Mr. Cruise, "Your kind is headed for extinction."

title: Industrial Sector Struggled in July
summary: Manufacturing output, the biggest component of industrial production, fell 0.4% last month from June. WASHINGTON-U.S. industrial output fell in July, as the manufacturing sector continued to struggle with trade-related headwinds.

title: Sean McVay's Biggest Problem: All of the Sean McVay Wannabes
summary: The Rams head coach and wunderkind enters a critical second act: adjusting his own approach to stay ahead of a league trying to emulate him.. Irvine, Calif.

title: Data Errors Plague Stock Traders in Volatile Week
summary: String of glitches follows incident with NYSE data feed. Volatile stock markets, recession fears and the U.S.-China trade fight have traders on edge. Now, they are grappling with another problem: garbled data.

title: Dealers Dangle Deals to Move Outgoing Models
summary: Vehicles are piling up at dealerships as the U.S. auto market cools, forcing steeper discounts. Dealership lots remain crowded with aging vehicles at a time when car companies typically focus on selling newer models, posing a threat to dealers' profits while promising bigger discounts for shoppers.

title: UPS Ventures Invests in Self-Driving Trucking Startup
summary: UPS, startup TuSimple expand partnership to test transportation of goods in autonomous vehicles. United Parcel Service Inc.'s venture-capital division, UPS Ventures, has acquired a minority stake in self-driving trucking startup TuSimple Inc., signaling the delivery company's continued push into autonomous driving.

title: The Indoor Farmer Who Wants to Remake Appalachia's Agriculture
summary: A startup called AppHarvest is building a 60-acre greenhouse in an economically distressed part of Kentucky. Will its high-tech approach help fix the U.S. food system?. Author

title: Activist Urges Care.com to Explore Sale
summary: Engine Capital says in letter that the child-care network has lost trust of users. An activist investor is urging Care.com , the largest marketplace for online caregivers, to pursue a sale, saying the company is "at a crossroads."

title: Inside a Rental Apartment That Looks Like an Old-World Hotel
summary: Fusing influences and colors he's brought to high-end projects like the Chateau Marmont, designer Fernando Santangelo-whose aesthetic client Bette Midler describes as witty and well-informed-trains his eye on his own rented brownstone. The next time you ignore a call from an unknown number, consider the case of Fernando Santangelo. On a spring day early in his career, an unidentified man rang his office in New York and explained that his wife had just been to the Chateau Marmont, the fantasy French-revival castle-turned-hotel on L.A.'s Sunset Strip, and admired the coquettish lampshades Santangelo had made for the lobby. She'd asked the front desk for his number, which they provided. Would he be willing to meet?

title: Inside Textile Artist Sheila Hicks's Paris Studio
summary: For six decades, artist Sheila Hicks has been pushing the boundaries of her chosen medium, fiber, and in the process, challenging conceptions of art more broadly. WSJ. goes inside her 6th arrondissement studio in Paris to see several works in progress. The 85-year-old Paris-based American artist Sheila Hicks officially speaks three languages-English, French and Spanish-but her most remarkable fluency is with the yarn she weaves, wraps, knots and assembles into her monumental works of art.

title: Inside Textile Artist Sheila Hicks's Paris Studio
summary: For six decades, artist Sheila Hicks has been pushing the boundaries of her chosen medium, fiber, and in the process, challenging conceptions of art more broadly. summary: Washington prods longtime adversaries on intelligence sharing, military cooperation against a common threat.

title: Lumber Liquidators: Get in on the Ground Floor
summary: Despite a pinch from Chinese tariffs, shares are too cheap to ignore. Stop us if you've heard this one before: Lumber Liquidators looks interesting here.

title: Electronic Arts Has More Than a Sporting Chance
summary: New games and coming console cycle should drive videogame publisher's shares higher. A bit off its game last year, Electronic Arts is in a good position to start leveling up.

title: Letter From Jailed New Zealand Shooter Was Posted Online
summary: White supremacist charged in the mosque attacks that killed 51 people was permitted to send letters to supporters, in violation of rules. The white supremacist charged in the New Zealand mosque attacks that killed 51 people was permitted to send letters to supporters from jail, authorities in the country said, including one that was posted to a forum that has been a home for racist and violent views.

title: Chip Maker Nvidia Faces Demand Pressure
summary: Chip maker's results could signal whether its shift to supplying chips to data centers is working. Chip maker Nvidia Corp. is expected to report fiscal second-quarter earnings after the market closes Thursday. The results come as Nvidia tries to broaden its market reach from being a dominant seller of graphics chips used by computer gamers into furnishing equipment to huge data centers amid a boom in cloud computing. Here's what to expect:

title: States Install 'Baby Boxes' to Protect Unwanted Infants
summary: Incubator-like devices allow parents to anonymously surrender newborns at fire stations and hospitals. For volunteer firefighters in Coolspring, Ind., a buzzing pager could mean a house fire, a trapped elevator, a highway wreckage-or a baby in a box.

title: The Startups Safeguarding Real Estate Against Schemers and Scammers
summary: Wire-transfer fraud cost 11,300 victims nearly $150 million last year, according to the FBI. These firms want to do something about it. Tom Cronkright learned the hard way that the real-estate industry needs better ways to protect itself and consumers from wire-transfer fraud.

title: Huawei Technicians Helped African Governments Spy on Political Opponents
summary: Employees embedded with cybersecurity forces in Uganda and Zambia intercepted encrypted communications and used cell data to track opponents, according to a Wall Street Journal investigation. KAMPALA, Uganda-Huawei Technologies Co., the world's largest telecommunications company, dominates African markets, where it has sold security tools that governments use for digital surveillance and censorship.

title: Judges Set to Rule on Cardinal George Pell's Child Sex-Abuse Appeal
summary: The decision, which could order a retrial, quash the former Vatican finance chief's conviction or dismiss his appeal, will be broadcast on the internet. MELBOURNE, Australia-Cardinal George Pell, the most senior Vatican official ever to be jailed for child sexual abuse, could be freed next week if he wins his appeal against the conviction.

title: Manhattan, Brooklyn Rents Soar to New Highs
summary: New York City renters under pressure, as landlords cut concessions. Manhattan and Brooklyn rents in July surged to their highest levels in at least a decade, turning the hunt for an apartment into a madcap ordeal for some renters.

title: Hickenlooper Plans to End Democratic Presidential Campaign
summary: He may seek the seat of Republican Sen. Cory Gardner. WASHINGTON-Former Colorado Gov. John Hickenlooper plans to drop out of the 2020 presidential race on Thursday, as he considers launching a Senate campaign in his home state, according to a person familiar with his plans.

title: Warning Signs Point to a Global Slowdown
summary: Weakness in Germany and China puts pressure on record U.S. expansion, as recession risks rise. Warning signs pointing to a deepening global economic slowdown-and the risk of recession-are flashing more brightly.

title: Mortgage Lender Fights Connecticut Over Call-Center Workers
summary: 1st Alliance Lending faces financial uncertainty after audit over unlicensed employees. Connecticut mortgage lender 1st Alliance Lending's fortunes were rising in 2016 when it was awarded a multimillion-dollar package of state subsidies to help expand the company to 300 employees. Now, the firm says it is verging on ruin after a dispute with state regulators.

title: U.S. Women's Soccer Team Ends Mediation Talks Without Agreement
summary: The two-day talks between the players and the U.S. Soccer Federation were an effort to settle a gender-discrimination lawsuit. The U.S. women's soccer team ended mediation talks with the U.S. Soccer Federation on Wednesday without reaching an agreement in its gender-discrimination lawsuit, an ominous sign for the acrimonious battle between soccer's domestic governing body and the best women's team in the world.

title: Cisco's Outlook Dampened by China Slowdown, Trade Dispute
summary: Maker of switches and internet routers gives tepid revenue growth forecast as it works to expand portfolio. Cisco Systems Inc. closed the business year with the largest revenue increase since 2013 but projected disappointing growth this quarter on lower spending from telecommunication companies and weakness in China.

title: Trump Ties Trade Deal to China Action in Hong Kong
summary: Beijing must respond 'humanely' to protests, U.S. president warns as public statements show a shift in tone. WASHINGTON-President Trump suggested a "personal meeting" with China's President Xi Jinping to discuss the escalating crisis in Hong Kong and warned China it must respond "humanely" to the protests if it wants to strike a trade deal.

title: New York City Council Members Move to Expand Health Care for Uninsured
summary: Speaker Corey Johnson unveiled a plan that would expand a program Mayor Bill de Blasio recently launched. New York City Council Speaker Corey Johnson unveiled a health-care plan that would expand a program Mayor Bill de Blasio recently launched to reduce emergency-room visits at public hospitals and provide services for the uninsured.

title: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Resume Subscription. The 2018 import value of Chinese goods subject to U.S. tariffs set to take effect on Sept. 1 is about $111 billion, and the total 2018 value of those items plus those with tariffs deferred to Dec. 15 is about $267 billion. A Page One article on Wednesday about the Trump administration plan to delay some tariffs incorrectly reported the values as $107 billion and $262 billion, respectively.
